Courses                          Steinhardt Course  EVALUATION RESULTS                     Physical Therapy Courses            The list below includes courses that have been offered within the past five years. Since many courses are offered only infrequently or on a rotating basis or have only been approved recently or as pilot courses, please check the current schedule of classes or ALBERT for the most up-to-date listing of current courses.    Click on a course name to view a description.                  Course Listing                          Course Number       Title       Hours       Units                            PT-GE 2610            Advanced Anatomy, Physiology, and Pathophysiology of the Musculoskeletal System           This course enables the student to understand advanced knowledge of the musculoskeletal system & knowledge of the interaction of this system with the neuromuscular, cardiovascular pulmonary, integumentary, endocrine, reproductive & digestive systems. The advanced knowledge will include synthesizing histology, physiology, pathophysiology, & pathophysiology effects on the musculoskeletal system.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2605            Advanced Evidence-Based Orthopedic Physical Therapy           This course enables the student to integrate knowledge in physical therapy with statistics & research design to critically analyze current physical therapy literature.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2601            Advanced Physical Therapy Examination and Intervention Skills of the Musculoskeletal System I           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on the examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2602            Advanced Physical Therapy Examination and Intervention Skills of the Musculoskeletal System II           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on the examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2603            Advanced Physical Therapy Examination and Intervention Skills of the Musculoskeletal System III           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on the examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2116            Analysis and Synthesis of Human Motion I           Integration of facts & principles derived from the fields of anatomy, physiology, & biomechanics with implications for normal, physical activity, conditioning, & therapeutic exercise; research approach.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2118            Analysis and Synthesis of Human Motion II           Analysis of abnormal motion & the procedures employed in its modification.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2024            Applied Anatomy/ Physiology of the Cardiopulmonary System           In-depth knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the cardiac, circulatory & pulmonary systems. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2230            Applied Anatomy/Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System           In depth-knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the muscular & skeletal systems. Anatomical models & specimens complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2232            Applied Anatomy/Physiology of the Neuromuscular System           In-depth knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the central, peripheral, & autonomic nervous systems & their relationship to the muscular system. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2233            Applied Anatomy/Physiology of the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary and Endocrinology Systems           In-depth knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the reproduction, renal, integumentary & endocrine systems. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2212            Aseptic Techniques/Infection & Disease Control           Basic aseptic techniques including practice of universal precautions to prevent infection, cross-contamination, & spread of bacterial, fungal & viral infections.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2295            Business Practices/Reimbursement/ Marketing/ Technology/ Management of Care Delivery System           Implementation of marketing plans & related public relations activities; major reimbursement guidelines; how to reflect patient or client care activities in all billing; apply time management principles to patient or client treatment scheduling; & understand & exhibit responsibility for practicing within the guidelines of third party payers.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2451            Clinical Affiliation I           This experience will enable the student to: participate in clinical education to enhance knowledge, values, & skills as a practitioner: & integrate & apply course work in the clinical setting.      Course Page               40    3            PT-GE 2452            Clinical Affiliation II           This experience will enable the student to: participate in clinical education to enhance knowledge values, & skills as a practitioner; & integrate & apply all course work in the clinical setting.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2455            Clinical Observation I           This experience will enable the student to participate in clinical education through observation of master clinicians.      Course Page               1 day per wk/3 wks    1            PT-GE 2456            Clinical Observation II           This experience will enable the student to particiapte in clinical education through obersvation of master clinicians.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2457            Clinical Observation III           This experience will enable the student to particiapte in clinical education through obersvation of master clinicians.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2458            Clinical Observation IV           This experience will enable the student to particiapte in clinical education through obersvation of master clinicians.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2410            Clinical Practice Seminar I           A seminar discussing clinical practice experience in the application of physical therapy procedures with developmental disabilities as it applies to current law & regulations concerning persons with developmental disabilities of all ages.      Course Page               20    1            PT-GE 2411            Clinical Practice Seminar II           Clinical practice experience in the application of physical therapy procedures with developmental disabilities.      Course Page               20    1            PT-GE 2412            Clinical Practice Seminar III           Provides the opportunity for students to develop skill & discriminating judgment in the planning & execution of progressive treatment programs in accordance with the relating physical therapy practice to theory in testing persons with developmental disabilities.      Course Page               40    2            PT-GE 2231            Clinical Science/Pathology/Pharmacology/Imaging of the Musculoskeletal System           Analysis of the etiology, pathology & clinical sciences of muscular & skeletal diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2026            Clinical Sciences/ Pathology of the Cardiopulmonary System           Analysis of the etiology, pathology, & clinical sciences of cardiac, circulatory & pulmonary diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/ laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2242            Clinical Sciences/Pathology/Pharmacology/Imaging of the Neuromuscular System           Analysis of the etiology, pathology & clinical sciences of neuromuscular diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2243            Clinical Sciences/Pathology/Pharmacology/Imaging of the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary and Endocrinology Systems           Analysis of the etiology, pathology & clinical sciences of reproductive, renal, integumentary & endocrine diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2030            CPR/First Aid/Advanced Emergency Techniques           This course will provide the student with all of the skills necessary to take appropriate action in an emergency in any practice setting.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2286            Critical Inquiry and Clinical Decision Making I (Review of the Literature)           This course will enable the student to utilize critical inquiry by applying the principles of scientific method to read & interpret professional literature. The student will apply the principles of clinical decision-making in the delivery of patient or client care to include: identification of problem, collection & interpretation of data, formulation of hypothesis, collection of data, interpretation of findings, acceptance or rejection of hypothesis, determination of clinical decision, deliberate action, & reevaluation of actions. The final outcome of this course will be a Review of Literature.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2287            Critical Inquiry and Clinical Decision Making II           Design & implementation of decision-making guidelines in order to utilize outcome effectiveness & efficiently studies to establish, implement, & evaluate the effectiveness of patient or client protocols. The student will use a case report as a vehicle for identifying clinical problems, assessing measuring devices, & collection & interpreting data to aid in clinical decision-making.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2288            Critical Inquiry/Clinical Decision Making III           Students will integrate knowledge in physical therapy with statistics & research design to critically analyze current physical therapy literature. Each student will be able to develop a research plan with a given topic.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 3006            Departmental Seminar: Physical Therapy           Seminar for doctoral students.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2400            Developmental Disabilities: Introduction for the Physical Therapist           Overview of topics concerning people with developmental disabilities. Introduction of terminology & etiological concepts. Definitions of the scope of practice & models of delivery. Examination of the roles of related health professions.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 3010            Doctoral Colloquium: Physical Therapy           Required every semester of all doctoral students who are working on their proposal/dissertations. Taken in lieu of Doctoral Advisement Fee. Provides an opportunity for students to share the most recent development of their proposals/dissertations. Students are expected to report on their own research projects & critique the projects of others in the class. Presentations on research design, statistics, procedures for validity & reliability measures, & grant-writing skills are included.      Course Page               15    0/1 (alt)            PT-GE 2218            Electrotherapeutic Modalities           Application of electrotherapeutic modalities, including alternating, direct, & pulsed current (e.g. high voltage galvanic stimulation, interferential current), neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), functional electrical stimulation (FES) for improving posture for movement, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), iontophoresis, electrical muscle stimulation, & biofeedback in order to: modulate or decrease pain; reduce or eliminate soft tissue inflammation caused by musculoskeltelal, neuromuscular, peripheral vascular, or integumentary injury, disease, developmental delay, or surgery; maintain strength after injury or surgery; decrease unwanted muscular activity; assist muscle contraction in gait or other functional training; or increase the rate of healing of open wounds.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2225            Exercise Physiology           Physiological & pathophysiological principles for understanding the response of the human body to exercise. The musculoskeletal, pulmonary, cardiovascular & metabolic responses to exercise & their implications in physical therapy intervention will be explored. The effects of aging, nutrition & environmental stress on the body?s performance will be discussed. Human energy expenditures, body composition & effects of training are presented in lectures & are coordinated with laboratory demonstration & experiences      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2229            Fitness Theory & Practice           Theoretical & practical aspects of physical fitness. Students to evaluate, design, & implement fitness & conditioning programs. Health, safety, injury prevention will be discussed. The importance of an active lifestyle, as a health behavior, & the role of physical activity in preventing cardiovascular disease & promoting health & longevity will be discussed.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2120            Gross Human Anatomy           Overview of human anatomy of the muscular, skeletal, nervous, & circulatory systems. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2004            Histology/ General Pathology           Overview of microanatomical structure from the perspective of cells, tissues, & systems. The four tissue types are studied including epithelial, connective, nervous, & muscular tissues. Basic concepts of cell & tissue injury & disease are presented, including examination of acute & chronic inflammation & immune & autoimmune responses.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2220            Kinesiology/Biomechanics/Ergonomics           Study of normal & abnormal human motion including gait & posture. Macrophysiological & biomechanical principles will be defined & applied to static & dynamic movement. Once developed, basic concepts are applied to specific joints, the trunk & spine.      Course Page               75    5            PT-GE 2209            Lifespan Development           In-depth knowledge of human development throughout the life cycle. The student will be given the foundation upon which typical & atypical behavior may be compared.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2008            Manual Techniques           This course enables the student to apply manual therapy (including mobilization & manipulation) which consists of a broad group of passive intervention in which physical therapists use their hands to modulate pain, increase joint range of motion, reduce soft tissue inflammation, induce relaxation, improve contractile & noncontractile tissue extensibility, & improve pulmonary function.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2187            Measurement and Evaluation in Human Motion I           The theoretical basis, principles, & techniques of kinesiological electromyography & motion analysis of normal & abnormal human motion.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2188            Measurement and Evaluation in Human Motion II           The theoretical basis, principles, & techniques of dynamometry; the integration of kinesiological electromyography, motion analysis, & dynamomtry.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2189            Measurement and Evaluation of Human Motion III           An introduction to the use of the LabVIEW computer programming language for the collection, manipulation, & processing data collected from the instruments that measure various aspects of human movement. Examples of instruments include electromyographs (EMG), dynamometers (e.g., Biodex), & electrogoniomemters. LabVIEW is a graphical programming language that uses software to stimulate hardware devices that may be custom-tailored to meet the needs of researchers. LabVIEW utilizes a series of icons that represent data collection, mathematical, statistical, & file management functions. Icons are ?wired? together to establish a directional flow of information in somewhat the same way that transistors, diodes, & computer chips are wired or soldered together on circuit boards. Data may be displayed in various graphical or tabular formats in real time or saved to memory for later analysis.      Course Page               48    3            PT-GE 2611            Mentored Orthopedic Physical Therapy Clinical Practice I           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on t he examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               532-537    0            PT-GE 2612            Mentored Orthopedic Physical Therapy Clinical Practice II           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on t he examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               532-537    0            PT-GE 2613            Mentored Orthopedic Physical Therapy Clinical Practice III           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on t he examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               532-537    0            PT-UE 0439            Orientation to Physical Rehabilitation           No Course Description Available      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2215            Physical Agents and Mechanicals Modalities (Including Aseptic Techniques/Infection & Disease Control)           Enables students to apply physical agents & aseptic techniques, including deep thermal modalities (e.g. ultrasound), a thermal modalities (e.g. pulsed ultrasound, pulsed electromagnetic fields), superficial thermotherapy (e.g. heat, paraffin baths, hot packs, fluidotherapy), cryotherapy modalities (cold packs, ice massage), hydrotherapy (e.g. whirlpools, tanks, contrast baths), & phototherapies (e.g. ultraviolet)in order to increase connective tissue extensibilities; modulate pain, reduce or eliminate soft tissue inflammation & swelling caused by musculoskeletal injuries or circulatory dysfunction; increase the healing rate of open wounds & soft tissue; remodel scar tissue; or treat skin conditions. Basic aseptic techniques including bacterial, fungal., & viral infections.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2250            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Cardiopulmonary System           The course will enable the student to: independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with a cardiopulmonary problem by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examination data to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnosis for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2251            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Musculoskeletal System           The course will enable the student to: independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with a musculoskeletal problem by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examination data to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnoses for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2252            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Neuromuscular System           Student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with a neuromuscular problem by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examination data to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnoses for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information      Course Page               75    5            PT-GE 2253            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary and Endocrinology Systems           The course will enable the student to: independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with ob/gyn, integumentary or endocrine problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examinations & to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnoses for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information.      Course Page               60    3            PT-GE 2263            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Program/Wellness Programs for the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary & Endocrinology System           Student to establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes within available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical intervention to achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability; promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, impairment, disease, disability & health risks related to age, gender, culture & lifestyle; provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to p[patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patient?s or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2260            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Programs/ Wellness Programs for the Cardiopulmonary System           Student will establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes within available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical therapy intervention to achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability. Promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, impairment, disease, disability & health risks related to age, gender, culture, & lifestyle; provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patient?s or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2261            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Programs/ Wellness Programs for the Musculoskeletal System           Students will establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes with available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical therapy intervention of achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability; promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, impairment , disease, disability & health risks related to age, gender, culture & lifestyle; provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patient?s or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities,      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2262            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Programs/ Wellness Programs for the Neuromuscular System           The course will enable the student to establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes within available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical therapy intervention to achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability; promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patients or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities.      Course Page               90    6            PT-GE 2401            Physical Therapy Management of Developmental Disabilities I           Principles & procedures of Physical Therapy evaluation & treatment of developmental disabilities. Reviewed of current neurobiological theories, clinical application, & discussion with emphasis on handling techniques.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2402            Physical Therapy Management of Developmental Disabilities II           Designed to enable a student to integrate knowledge of neurophysiology & neurobehavior with physical therapy evaluation & treatment of motor dysfunction in persons with developmental disabilities. Treatment methods currently in use are compared & contrasted.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 3001            Practicum in Pathokinesiology Research I           Experience in clinical research centers under supervision of experienced clinical researchers of problems concerned with human motion of cardiopulmonary function.      Course Page               90    3            PT-GE 3002            Practicum in Pathokinesiology Research II           Experience in clinical research centers under supervision of experienced clinical researchers of problems concerned with human motion of cardiopulmonary function.      Course Page               90    3            PT-GE 2219            Prescription, Fabrication, & Application of Assistive, Adaptive, Supportive & Protective Devices & Equipment           Enables the student to: understand the physical properties & biomechanical principles of devises & equipment; to prescribe, apply, & fabricate as appropriate adaptive, orthotic, protective, supportive, & prosthetic devices & equipment for ADL & IADL; to analyze their use during ADL & IADL; & to evaluate the limitations & indications/contra indications of devises & equipment. The course enables the student to practice fabricating adaptive, supportivew, & protective devices.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2439            Principles and Practices of Management in the Health Profession           Presents the elements of the managerial process & its application to the various physical therapy work situations. Designed to prepare physical therapists in the application of management principles & practices of hospitals & health institutions of physical therapy, as well as to prepare physical therapists for the process of consultation in physical therapy.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2227            Principles of Exercise           Analysis of the underlying principles of the following types of therapeutic exercise: stretching, strengthening; active assistive; active; resistive, using manual resistance pulleys, weights, hydraulics, elastics, robotics, & mechanical or electromechanical devices: neuromuscular relation, inhibition & facilitation; neuromuscular reeducation; motor training or retraining; developmental; activities; breathing exercises, including ventilatory muscle training; aerobics endurance activities, using cycles, treadmills, steppers, pools, manual resistance, pulleys, weights, hydraulics, elastics, robotics, & mechanical or electromechanical devised; aquatics exercises; & conditioning & reconditioning.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2281            Professional Behavior           History of the profession, the professional association, professionalism, individual & cultural differences, health professional/patient relationships, medical & professional ethics, & medical legal aspects of care. The student demonstrates professional behaviors in all interactions with patients, clients, families, caregivers, & other health care providers. Enables the student to practice in a safe setting & manner to minimize risk to the patient, client, therapist, & others; be aware of the practices & ramifications of sexual harassment; identify & assess the health needs of individuals, groups, & communities including screening, prevention, & wellness programs appropriate to physical therapy; display generously as evidenced by the use of time & effort to meet patient or client needs; & demonstrate social responsibility, citizenship, & advocacy including participation in community & human service organizations & activities.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2282            Professional Behavior II (Risk Management/Sexual Harassment/Social Responsibility/Career Development)           This course will enable the student to: practice in a safe setting & manner to minimize risk to the patient; client, therapist, & others; be aware of the practices & ramifications of sexual harassment; identify & assess the health needs of individuals, group & communities including screening, prevention, & wellness programs appropriate to physical therapy; display generosity as evidenced by the use of time & effort to meet patient or client needs; demonstrate social responsibility, citizenship, & advocacy including participation in community & human service organizations & activities; provide pro bono services; & formulate & implement a plan for personal & professional career development based upon self-assessment, reflection, & feedback from others.      Course Page               45    2            PT-GE 2016            Research in Physical Therapy I           Logic & scientific thinking; the identification of research problems; research methodology, analysis, & interpretation of data with specific reference to the physical therapy field.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2018            Research in Physical Therapy II           Logic & scientific thinking; the identification of research problems; research methodology, analysis, & interpretation of data with specific reference to the physical therapy field.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2604            Seminar: Orthopedic Physical Therapy           This course enables the student to integrate knowledge in physical therapy with motor learning, human growth & development, nutrition, pharmacology, medical diagnostic techniques, orthopedic surgery & performance as a disabled athlete & their impact on the musculoskeletal system.      Course Page               30    2/3 (alt)            PT-GE 2450            Six Week Observation /Hands On Clinical Affiliation           This experience will enable the student to: participate in clinical education to enhance knowledge, values, & skills as a practitioner; & integrate & apply course work in the clinical setting.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2019            The Physical Therapist as an Administrator/Delegator/ Manager           Management of human & material resources & services to provide quality, efficient & cost effective physical therapy services based upon patient?s or client?s goals; practice team building & group dynamic skills; interact with patients, clients, family members, other health care providers & community based organizations for the purpose of coordinating activities to facilitate efficient & effective patient or client care; delegate physical therapy related services to appropriate human resources; supervise & manage support personnel to whom tasks have been delegated; practice advocacy skills for patient & through participation in the legislative processes; & participate in management budgeting, billing & reimbursement activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2020            The Physical Therapist as an Educator/ Consultant/ Communicator           The course will enable the student to: provide patient related instruction; educate others using a variety of teaching methods that are commensurate with the needs & unique characteristics of the learner; provide consultative services using the physical therapist?s skills to individuals, businesses, schools, government agencies, or other organizations; expressively & receptively communicate with patients, clients, family caregivers, practitioners, consumers, payers & policy makers; & take responsibility for communication or discussion of diagnoses or clinical impressions with other practitioners.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2303            Topics in Physical Therapy: Women's Health           This course enable practicing physical therapists to gain knowledge about the female's genito-urinary system, to understand anatomical & physiological changes occurring during pregnancy, to perform physical therapy examination on a live model, & to establish & implement an intervention plan for females with disorders of the genito-urinary system.      Course Page               10    1            PT-GE 2190            Typical and Atypical Motor Development: Birth to Two Years           Designed to provide the student with a detailed knowledge of typical & pathological motor development during the first two years of life. RESULTS                     Physical Therapy Courses            The list below includes courses that have been offered within the past five years. Since many courses are offered only infrequently or on a rotating basis or have only been approved recently or as pilot courses, please check the current schedule of classes or ALBERT for the most up-to-date listing of current courses.    Click on a course name to view a description.                  Course Listing                          Course Number       Title       Hours       Units                            PT-GE 2610            Advanced Anatomy, Physiology, and Pathophysiology of the Musculoskeletal System           This course enables the student to understand advanced knowledge of the musculoskeletal system & knowledge of the interaction of this system with the neuromuscular, cardiovascular pulmonary, integumentary, endocrine, reproductive & digestive systems. The advanced knowledge will include synthesizing histology, physiology, pathophysiology, & pathophysiology effects on the musculoskeletal system.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2605            Advanced Evidence-Based Orthopedic Physical Therapy           This course enables the student to integrate knowledge in physical therapy with statistics & research design to critically analyze current physical therapy literature.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2601            Advanced Physical Therapy Examination and Intervention Skills of the Musculoskeletal System I           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on the examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2602            Advanced Physical Therapy Examination and Intervention Skills of the Musculoskeletal System II           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on the examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2603            Advanced Physical Therapy Examination and Intervention Skills of the Musculoskeletal System III           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on the examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2116            Analysis and Synthesis of Human Motion I           Integration of facts & principles derived from the fields of anatomy, physiology, & biomechanics with implications for normal, physical activity, conditioning, & therapeutic exercise; research approach.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2118            Analysis and Synthesis of Human Motion II           Analysis of abnormal motion & the procedures employed in its modification.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2024            Applied Anatomy/ Physiology of the Cardiopulmonary System           In-depth knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the cardiac, circulatory & pulmonary systems. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2230            Applied Anatomy/Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System           In depth-knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the muscular & skeletal systems. Anatomical models & specimens complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2232            Applied Anatomy/Physiology of the Neuromuscular System           In-depth knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the central, peripheral, & autonomic nervous systems & their relationship to the muscular system. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2233            Applied Anatomy/Physiology of the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary and Endocrinology Systems           In-depth knowledge of human anatomy & the principles of regulation of function of the reproduction, renal, integumentary & endocrine systems. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2212            Aseptic Techniques/Infection & Disease Control           Basic aseptic techniques including practice of universal precautions to prevent infection, cross-contamination, & spread of bacterial, fungal & viral infections.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2295            Business Practices/Reimbursement/ Marketing/ Technology/ Management of Care Delivery System           Implementation of marketing plans & related public relations activities; major reimbursement guidelines; how to reflect patient or client care activities in all billing; apply time management principles to patient or client treatment scheduling; & understand & exhibit responsibility for practicing within the guidelines of third party payers.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2451            Clinical Affiliation I           This experience will enable the student to: participate in clinical education to enhance knowledge, values, & skills as a practitioner: & integrate & apply course work in the clinical setting.      Course Page               40    3            PT-GE 2452            Clinical Affiliation II           This experience will enable the student to: participate in clinical education to enhance knowledge values, & skills as a practitioner; & integrate & apply all course work in the clinical setting.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2455            Clinical Observation I           This experience will enable the student to participate in clinical education through observation of master clinicians.      Course Page               1 day per wk/3 wks    1            PT-GE 2456            Clinical Observation II           This experience will enable the student to particiapte in clinical education through obersvation of master clinicians.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2457            Clinical Observation III           This experience will enable the student to particiapte in clinical education through obersvation of master clinicians.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2458            Clinical Observation IV           This experience will enable the student to particiapte in clinical education through obersvation of master clinicians.      Course Page               15    1            PT-GE 2410            Clinical Practice Seminar I           A seminar discussing clinical practice experience in the application of physical therapy procedures with developmental disabilities as it applies to current law & regulations concerning persons with developmental disabilities of all ages.      Course Page               20    1            PT-GE 2411            Clinical Practice Seminar II           Clinical practice experience in the application of physical therapy procedures with developmental disabilities.      Course Page               20    1            PT-GE 2412            Clinical Practice Seminar III           Provides the opportunity for students to develop skill & discriminating judgment in the planning & execution of progressive treatment programs in accordance with the relating physical therapy practice to theory in testing persons with developmental disabilities.      Course Page               40    2            PT-GE 2231            Clinical Science/Pathology/Pharmacology/Imaging of the Musculoskeletal System           Analysis of the etiology, pathology & clinical sciences of muscular & skeletal diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2026            Clinical Sciences/ Pathology of the Cardiopulmonary System           Analysis of the etiology, pathology, & clinical sciences of cardiac, circulatory & pulmonary diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/ laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2242            Clinical Sciences/Pathology/Pharmacology/Imaging of the Neuromuscular System           Analysis of the etiology, pathology & clinical sciences of neuromuscular diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2243            Clinical Sciences/Pathology/Pharmacology/Imaging of the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary and Endocrinology Systems           Analysis of the etiology, pathology & clinical sciences of reproductive, renal, integumentary & endocrine diseases, disorders, & disabilities. Imaging techniques & clinical/laboratory assessment techniques & pharmacological interventions will be presented.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2030            CPR/First Aid/Advanced Emergency Techniques           This course will provide the student with all of the skills necessary to take appropriate action in an emergency in any practice setting.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2286            Critical Inquiry and Clinical Decision Making I (Review of the Literature)           This course will enable the student to utilize critical inquiry by applying the principles of scientific method to read & interpret professional literature. The student will apply the principles of clinical decision-making in the delivery of patient or client care to include: identification of problem, collection & interpretation of data, formulation of hypothesis, collection of data, interpretation of findings, acceptance or rejection of hypothesis, determination of clinical decision, deliberate action, & reevaluation of actions. The final outcome of this course will be a Review of Literature.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2287            Critical Inquiry and Clinical Decision Making II           Design & implementation of decision-making guidelines in order to utilize outcome effectiveness & efficiently studies to establish, implement, & evaluate the effectiveness of patient or client protocols. The student will use a case report as a vehicle for identifying clinical problems, assessing measuring devices, & collection & interpreting data to aid in clinical decision-making.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2288            Critical Inquiry/Clinical Decision Making III           Students will integrate knowledge in physical therapy with statistics & research design to critically analyze current physical therapy literature. Each student will be able to develop a research plan with a given topic.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 3006            Departmental Seminar: Physical Therapy           Seminar for doctoral students.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2400            Developmental Disabilities: Introduction for the Physical Therapist           Overview of topics concerning people with developmental disabilities. Introduction of terminology & etiological concepts. Definitions of the scope of practice & models of delivery. Examination of the roles of related health professions.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 3010            Doctoral Colloquium: Physical Therapy           Required every semester of all doctoral students who are working on their proposal/dissertations. Taken in lieu of Doctoral Advisement Fee. Provides an opportunity for students to share the most recent development of their proposals/dissertations. Students are expected to report on their own research projects & critique the projects of others in the class. Presentations on research design, statistics, procedures for validity & reliability measures, & grant-writing skills are included.      Course Page               15    0/1 (alt)            PT-GE 2218            Electrotherapeutic Modalities           Application of electrotherapeutic modalities, including alternating, direct, & pulsed current (e.g. high voltage galvanic stimulation, interferential current), neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES), functional electrical stimulation (FES) for improving posture for movement, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), iontophoresis, electrical muscle stimulation, & biofeedback in order to: modulate or decrease pain; reduce or eliminate soft tissue inflammation caused by musculoskeltelal, neuromuscular, peripheral vascular, or integumentary injury, disease, developmental delay, or surgery; maintain strength after injury or surgery; decrease unwanted muscular activity; assist muscle contraction in gait or other functional training; or increase the rate of healing of open wounds.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2225            Exercise Physiology           Physiological & pathophysiological principles for understanding the response of the human body to exercise. The musculoskeletal, pulmonary, cardiovascular & metabolic responses to exercise & their implications in physical therapy intervention will be explored. The effects of aging, nutrition & environmental stress on the body?s performance will be discussed. Human energy expenditures, body composition & effects of training are presented in lectures & are coordinated with laboratory demonstration & experiences      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2229            Fitness Theory & Practice           Theoretical & practical aspects of physical fitness. Students to evaluate, design, & implement fitness & conditioning programs. Health, safety, injury prevention will be discussed. The importance of an active lifestyle, as a health behavior, & the role of physical activity in preventing cardiovascular disease & promoting health & longevity will be discussed.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2120            Gross Human Anatomy           Overview of human anatomy of the muscular, skeletal, nervous, & circulatory systems. Anatomical models & specimens will complement didactic classroom activities.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2004            Histology/ General Pathology           Overview of microanatomical structure from the perspective of cells, tissues, & systems. The four tissue types are studied including epithelial, connective, nervous, & muscular tissues. Basic concepts of cell & tissue injury & disease are presented, including examination of acute & chronic inflammation & immune & autoimmune responses.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2220            Kinesiology/Biomechanics/Ergonomics           Study of normal & abnormal human motion including gait & posture. Macrophysiological & biomechanical principles will be defined & applied to static & dynamic movement. Once developed, basic concepts are applied to specific joints, the trunk & spine.      Course Page               75    5            PT-GE 2209            Lifespan Development           In-depth knowledge of human development throughout the life cycle. The student will be given the foundation upon which typical & atypical behavior may be compared.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2008            Manual Techniques           This course enables the student to apply manual therapy (including mobilization & manipulation) which consists of a broad group of passive intervention in which physical therapists use their hands to modulate pain, increase joint range of motion, reduce soft tissue inflammation, induce relaxation, improve contractile & noncontractile tissue extensibility, & improve pulmonary function.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2187            Measurement and Evaluation in Human Motion I           The theoretical basis, principles, & techniques of kinesiological electromyography & motion analysis of normal & abnormal human motion.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2188            Measurement and Evaluation in Human Motion II           The theoretical basis, principles, & techniques of dynamometry; the integration of kinesiological electromyography, motion analysis, & dynamomtry.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2189            Measurement and Evaluation of Human Motion III           An introduction to the use of the LabVIEW computer programming language for the collection, manipulation, & processing data collected from the instruments that measure various aspects of human movement. Examples of instruments include electromyographs (EMG), dynamometers (e.g., Biodex), & electrogoniomemters. LabVIEW is a graphical programming language that uses software to stimulate hardware devices that may be custom-tailored to meet the needs of researchers. LabVIEW utilizes a series of icons that represent data collection, mathematical, statistical, & file management functions. Icons are ?wired? together to establish a directional flow of information in somewhat the same way that transistors, diodes, & computer chips are wired or soldered together on circuit boards. Data may be displayed in various graphical or tabular formats in real time or saved to memory for later analysis.      Course Page               48    3            PT-GE 2611            Mentored Orthopedic Physical Therapy Clinical Practice I           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on t he examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               532-537    0            PT-GE 2612            Mentored Orthopedic Physical Therapy Clinical Practice II           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on t he examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               532-537    0            PT-GE 2613            Mentored Orthopedic Physical Therapy Clinical Practice III           This course enables the student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with musculoskeletal problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age-related tests & measure. The courses also enable the student: to provide direct physical therapy interventions to achieve patient/client outcomes based on t he examination & the impairments, functional limitations, & disabilities.      Course Page               532-537    0            PT-UE 0439            Orientation to Physical Rehabilitation           No Course Description Available      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2215            Physical Agents and Mechanicals Modalities (Including Aseptic Techniques/Infection & Disease Control)           Enables students to apply physical agents & aseptic techniques, including deep thermal modalities (e.g. ultrasound), a thermal modalities (e.g. pulsed ultrasound, pulsed electromagnetic fields), superficial thermotherapy (e.g. heat, paraffin baths, hot packs, fluidotherapy), cryotherapy modalities (cold packs, ice massage), hydrotherapy (e.g. whirlpools, tanks, contrast baths), & phototherapies (e.g. ultraviolet)in order to increase connective tissue extensibilities; modulate pain, reduce or eliminate soft tissue inflammation & swelling caused by musculoskeletal injuries or circulatory dysfunction; increase the healing rate of open wounds & soft tissue; remodel scar tissue; or treat skin conditions. Basic aseptic techniques including bacterial, fungal., & viral infections.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2250            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Cardiopulmonary System           The course will enable the student to: independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with a cardiopulmonary problem by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examination data to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnosis for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2251            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Musculoskeletal System           The course will enable the student to: independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with a musculoskeletal problem by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examination data to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnoses for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2252            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Neuromuscular System           Student to independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with a neuromuscular problem by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examination data to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnoses for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information      Course Page               75    5            PT-GE 2253            Physical Therapy Examinations of the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary and Endocrinology Systems           The course will enable the student to: independently examine & reexamine a patient or client with ob/gyn, integumentary or endocrine problems by obtaining a pertinent history from the patient or client & from other relevant sources, by performing relevant systems review, & by selecting appropriate age related tests & measure; synthesize examinations & to complete the physical therapy evaluation; engage in the diagnostic process in an efficient & cost-effective manner consistent with the policies & procedures of the practice setting; engage in the diagnostic process to establish differential diagnoses for patients across the life span; & determine patient or client prognoses based on evaluation of results of examinations & medical & psychosocial information.      Course Page               60    3            PT-GE 2263            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Program/Wellness Programs for the Ob/Gyn, Integumentary & Endocrinology System           Student to establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes within available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical intervention to achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability; promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, impairment, disease, disability & health risks related to age, gender, culture & lifestyle; provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to p[patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patient?s or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2260            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Programs/ Wellness Programs for the Cardiopulmonary System           Student will establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes within available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical therapy intervention to achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability. Promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, impairment, disease, disability & health risks related to age, gender, culture, & lifestyle; provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patient?s or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2261            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Programs/ Wellness Programs for the Musculoskeletal System           Students will establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes with available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical therapy intervention of achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability; promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, impairment , disease, disability & health risks related to age, gender, culture & lifestyle; provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patient?s or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities,      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2262            Physical Therapy Interventions/Prevention Programs/ Wellness Programs for the Neuromuscular System           The course will enable the student to establish a safe & effective physical therapy plan of care; establish goals & functional outcomes that specify expected time duration; define achievable patient or client outcomes within available resources; monitor & adjust the plan of care in response to patient or client status; provide direct physical therapy intervention to achieve patient or client outcomes based on the examination & on the impairment, functional limitations, & disability; promote optimal health by providing information on wellness, provide primary, secondary or tertiary care to patients in collaboration with other practitioners in settings supportive of comprehensive & complex services based on patients or client?s goals & expected functional outcomes & on knowledge of one?s own & other?s capabilities.      Course Page               90    6            PT-GE 2401            Physical Therapy Management of Developmental Disabilities I           Principles & procedures of Physical Therapy evaluation & treatment of developmental disabilities. Reviewed of current neurobiological theories, clinical application, & discussion with emphasis on handling techniques.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 2402            Physical Therapy Management of Developmental Disabilities II           Designed to enable a student to integrate knowledge of neurophysiology & neurobehavior with physical therapy evaluation & treatment of motor dysfunction in persons with developmental disabilities. Treatment methods currently in use are compared & contrasted.      Course Page               60    4            PT-GE 3001            Practicum in Pathokinesiology Research I           Experience in clinical research centers under supervision of experienced clinical researchers of problems concerned with human motion of cardiopulmonary function.      Course Page               90    3            PT-GE 3002            Practicum in Pathokinesiology Research II           Experience in clinical research centers under supervision of experienced clinical researchers of problems concerned with human motion of cardiopulmonary function.      Course Page               90    3            PT-GE 2219            Prescription, Fabrication, & Application of Assistive, Adaptive, Supportive & Protective Devices & Equipment           Enables the student to: understand the physical properties & biomechanical principles of devises & equipment; to prescribe, apply, & fabricate as appropriate adaptive, orthotic, protective, supportive, & prosthetic devices & equipment for ADL & IADL; to analyze their use during ADL & IADL; & to evaluate the limitations & indications/contra indications of devises & equipment. The course enables the student to practice fabricating adaptive, supportivew, & protective devices.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2439            Principles and Practices of Management in the Health Profession           Presents the elements of the managerial process & its application to the various physical therapy work situations. Designed to prepare physical therapists in the application of management principles & practices of hospitals & health institutions of physical therapy, as well as to prepare physical therapists for the process of consultation in physical therapy.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2227            Principles of Exercise           Analysis of the underlying principles of the following types of therapeutic exercise: stretching, strengthening; active assistive; active; resistive, using manual resistance pulleys, weights, hydraulics, elastics, robotics, & mechanical or electromechanical devices: neuromuscular relation, inhibition & facilitation; neuromuscular reeducation; motor training or retraining; developmental; activities; breathing exercises, including ventilatory muscle training; aerobics endurance activities, using cycles, treadmills, steppers, pools, manual resistance, pulleys, weights, hydraulics, elastics, robotics, & mechanical or electromechanical devised; aquatics exercises; & conditioning & reconditioning.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2281            Professional Behavior           History of the profession, the professional association, professionalism, individual & cultural differences, health professional/patient relationships, medical & professional ethics, & medical legal aspects of care. The student demonstrates professional behaviors in all interactions with patients, clients, families, caregivers, & other health care providers. Enables the student to practice in a safe setting & manner to minimize risk to the patient, client, therapist, & others; be aware of the practices & ramifications of sexual harassment; identify & assess the health needs of individuals, groups, & communities including screening, prevention, & wellness programs appropriate to physical therapy; display generously as evidenced by the use of time & effort to meet patient or client needs; & demonstrate social responsibility, citizenship, & advocacy including participation in community & human service organizations & activities.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2282            Professional Behavior II (Risk Management/Sexual Harassment/Social Responsibility/Career Development)           This course will enable the student to: practice in a safe setting & manner to minimize risk to the patient; client, therapist, & others; be aware of the practices & ramifications of sexual harassment; identify & assess the health needs of individuals, group & communities including screening, prevention, & wellness programs appropriate to physical therapy; display generosity as evidenced by the use of time & effort to meet patient or client needs; demonstrate social responsibility, citizenship, & advocacy including participation in community & human service organizations & activities; provide pro bono services; & formulate & implement a plan for personal & professional career development based upon self-assessment, reflection, & feedback from others.      Course Page               45    2            PT-GE 2016            Research in Physical Therapy I           Logic & scientific thinking; the identification of research problems; research methodology, analysis, & interpretation of data with specific reference to the physical therapy field.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2018            Research in Physical Therapy II           Logic & scientific thinking; the identification of research problems; research methodology, analysis, & interpretation of data with specific reference to the physical therapy field.      Course Page               30    3            PT-GE 2604            Seminar: Orthopedic Physical Therapy           This course enables the student to integrate knowledge in physical therapy with motor learning, human growth & development, nutrition, pharmacology, medical diagnostic techniques, orthopedic surgery & performance as a disabled athlete & their impact on the musculoskeletal system.      Course Page               30    2/3 (alt)            PT-GE 2450            Six Week Observation /Hands On Clinical Affiliation           This experience will enable the student to: participate in clinical education to enhance knowledge, values, & skills as a practitioner; & integrate & apply course work in the clinical setting.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2019            The Physical Therapist as an Administrator/Delegator/ Manager           Management of human & material resources & services to provide quality, efficient & cost effective physical therapy services based upon patient?s or client?s goals; practice team building & group dynamic skills; interact with patients, clients, family members, other health care providers & community based organizations for the purpose of coordinating activities to facilitate efficient & effective patient or client care; delegate physical therapy related services to appropriate human resources; supervise & manage support personnel to whom tasks have been delegated; practice advocacy skills for patient & through participation in the legislative processes; & participate in management budgeting, billing & reimbursement activities.      Course Page               45    3            PT-GE 2020            The Physical Therapist as an Educator/ Consultant/ Communicator           The course will enable the student to: provide patient related instruction; educate others using a variety of teaching methods that are commensurate with the needs & unique characteristics of the learner; provide consultative services using the physical therapist?s skills to individuals, businesses, schools, government agencies, or other organizations; expressively & receptively communicate with patients, clients, family caregivers, practitioners, consumers, payers & policy makers; & take responsibility for communication or discussion of diagnoses or clinical impressions with other practitioners.      Course Page               30    2            PT-GE 2303            Topics in Physical Therapy: Women's Health           This course enable practicing physical therapists to gain knowledge about the female's genito-urinary system, to understand anatomical & physiological changes occurring during pregnancy, to perform physical therapy examination on a live model, & to establish & implement an intervention plan for females with disorders of the genito-urinary system.      Course Page               10    1            PT-GE 2190            Typical and Atypical Motor Development: Birth to Two Years           Designed to provide the student with a detailed knowledge of typical & pathological motor development during the first two years of life. Fiscal Operations // Payroll       Primary Contacts    myTime    Adjuncts    Student and Federal Work-Study    Payroll Service Center          myTime    NYU myTime is an NYU-wide, web-based timekeeping system that provides NYU with a system for tracking time worked and time off balances. It provides administrators, staff, hourly student employees, and researchers with online access to vacation, sick, and personal time balances. myTime has supplanted paper and Excel-based time sheets.    For additional information about myTime including FAQs, training, etc. visit the myTime website .    Please be aware that in order to access NYU myTime from off-campus or outside of the NYU network, you will need to install and run VPN security software .    Adjuncts    Complete information regarding the collective bargaining agreement and adjunct benefits, including enrollment and claim forms and plan descriptions, can be found here .    Department administrators are reminded to update SIS before submitting adjunct instructor appointment paperwork.    Students and Federal Work-Study    Federal Work-Study (FWS) is an option only if both student and hiring department have sufficient FWS funds available. Once these funds are exhausted, the student will be paid out of the unit's non-FWS student worker account line.    Student Employee Payroll    Students must submit time sheets via myTime. Students are paid on a bi-weekly basis .    Please make sure that student employees under your supervision submit their time sheets promptly.    Wasserman Center for Career Development    The process for hiring a student (and any other part-time employee) is available here .    Student employees must visit the Wasserman Center and complete the required paperwork before their start date.    Disbursing Checks    Before disbursing a physical paycheck, the student must present picture identification and acknowledge receipt in writing. Upon receiving student paychecks from Payroll, department administrators should prepare a signature sheet listing the names of all students, the pay period end date, and a space for students to sign and date.    Paychecks should be kept in a locked, secure location.    If the department administrator delegates the task of disbursing checks to another person (e.g., a receptionist), that person should be made aware of these requirements as well.    back to top       Last reviewed Aril 22, 2014                    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University.
